message_1: Consider a square with side length 4 units. Subdivide this square into smaller squares of side length 1 unit. How many smaller squares will there be in the subdivision?
message_2:
When you subdivide a square with side length 4 units into smaller squares of side length 1 unit, you create a grid of 4 rows and 4 columns. To find the total number of smaller squares, you can multiply the number of rows by the number of columns: 

4 rows Ã— 4 columns = 16 smaller squares

So, there will be 16 smaller squares in the subdivision.
